articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Amazon of Illegally Protecting Monopoly in Online Retail
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon, saying its conduct in its online store and services to merchants illegally stifled competition.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon, saying its conduct in its online store and services to merchants illegally stifled competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon on Tuesday, setting up a long-awaited antitrust fight with the e-commerce giant that could alter the way Americans shop for everything from toilet paper to electronics online.

articles.headline: Groundswell of Democrats Builds Calling on Menendez to Resign
articles.snippet: The New Jersey Democrat’s indictment last week initially prompted only a handful of calls from within his party for his exit. But on Tuesday, the dam broke, led by colleagues facing re-election next year.
articles.abstract: The New Jersey Democrat’s indictment last week initially prompted only a handful of calls from within his party for his exit. But on Tuesday, the dam broke, led by colleagues facing re-election next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: A stampede of Senate Democrats led by some of the party’s most endangered incumbents rushed forward on Tuesday calling for Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey to resign, a day after he defiantly vowed to fight federal corruption charges and predicted he would be exonerated.

articles.headline: For Amazon’s Andy Jassy, a Cleanup Job Just Got a Lot Bigger
articles.snippet: The F.T.C. accused the internet giant of protecting an online retail monopoly and forcing higher prices onto consumers.
articles.abstract: The F.T.C. accused the internet giant of protecting an online retail monopoly and forcing higher prices onto consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the two years since Andy Jassy replaced Jeff Bezos as Amazon’s chief executive, he has been cleaning up after his company’s aggressive pandemic expansion and after Mr. Bezos. Mr. Jassy has reined in Amazon’s voracious warehouse growth, culled from the company’s sprawl of products and laid off thousands of employees on several of Mr. Bezos’ pet projects.

articles.headline: Target, Citing Theft, to Close Nine Stores
articles.snippet: The retailer will close locations in New York, San Francisco, Seattle and Portland, saying its business had been hurt and the safety of employees and customers was at risk.
articles.abstract: The retailer will close locations in New York, San Francisco, Seattle and Portland, saying its business had been hurt and the safety of employees and customers was at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Target announced on Tuesday that it was closing nine stores across four states, saying theft at the locations was harming its business and threatening the safety of employees and customers.

articles.headline: TV and Movie Writers to Begin Returning to Work on Wednesday
articles.snippet: The leadership of the Writers Guild of America voted to end a 148-day strike. Members will start voting on the deal’s ratification next week.
articles.abstract: The leadership of the Writers Guild of America voted to end a 148-day strike. Members will start voting on the deal’s ratification next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 148 days on strike, television and movie writers will begin returning to work on Wednesday.

articles.headline: E.U. Law Sets the Stage for a Clash Over Disinformation
articles.snippet: The law, aimed at forcing social media giants to adopt new policies to curb harmful content, is expected to face blowback from Elon Musk, who owns X.
articles.abstract: The law, aimed at forcing social media giants to adopt new policies to curb harmful content, is expected to face blowback from Elon Musk, who owns X.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Facebook page in Slovakia called Som z dediny, which means “I’m from the village,” trumpeted a debunked Russian claim last month that Ukraine’s president had secretly purchased a vacation home in Egypt under his mother-in-law’s name.

articles.headline: Lina Khan vs. Jeff Bezos: This Is Big Tech’s Real Cage Match
articles.snippet: The chair of the Federal Trade Commission wants to disrupt Amazon, whose founder built a trillion-dollar firm by disrupting retail.
articles.abstract: The chair of the Federal Trade Commission wants to disrupt Amazon, whose founder built a trillion-dollar firm by disrupting retail.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos made his fortune with one truly big idea: What if a retailer did everything possible to make customers happy?

articles.headline: America’s Black Cemeteries and Three Women Trying to Save Them
articles.snippet: In Georgia, Texas and Washington, D.C., three Black women are working to preserve desecrated African American burial grounds and the stories they hold.
articles.abstract: In Georgia, Texas and Washington, D.C., three Black women are working to preserve desecrated African American burial grounds and the stories they hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: The child’s headstone is inscribed simply “Nannie,” marking the grave of a 7-year-old girl who died on May 18, 1856. She is buried in one of Washington’s oldest Black cemeteries, in a neglected corner of Georgetown. For years she has touched visitors who have left toys, dolls and birthday cards at her grave.

articles.headline: The Sheriff, His Girlfriend and His Illegal Subpoenas
articles.snippet: Powerful figures in Mississippi, including the attorney general, two judges and a future congressman, learned how a sheriff lied to spy on his girlfriend. They all kept his secret.
articles.abstract: Powerful figures in Mississippi, including the attorney general, two judges and a future congressman, learned how a sheriff lied to spy on his girlfriend. They all kept his secret.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2014, Bryan Bailey, the sheriff of Rankin County, Miss., made what seemed like a series of routine requests of the local district attorney’s office.
articles.byline: By Ilyssa Daly and Jerry Mitchell

articles.headline: In Rare Alliance, Democrats and Republicans Seek Legal Power to Clear Homeless Camps
articles.snippet: Dozens of leaders, mostly from Western states, have asked the Supreme Court to overturn lower court decisions that restrict enforcement against public camping.
articles.abstract: Dozens of leaders, mostly from Western states, have asked the Supreme Court to overturn lower court decisions that restrict enforcement against public camping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Garbage, feces and needles run through the rivers in Missoula, Mont. On the streets of San Francisco, tents are so thick that sidewalks in the Tenderloin neighborhood have become “unofficial open-air public housing.” In Portland, Ore., a blaze shut down an on-ramp to the Steel Bridge for several days in March after campers tunneled through a cinder block wall and lit a campfire to stay warm.

articles.headline: FTX Chief Once Met With Powell. Now D.C. Crypto Lobbyists Are Struggling.
articles.snippet: FTX’s demise and its leader’s upcoming trial haven’t stopped a major lobbying push by the industry this week, but the events have changed its tone.
articles.abstract: FTX’s demise and its leader’s upcoming trial haven’t stopped a major lobbying push by the industry this week, but the events have changed its tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cryptocurrency lobbyists were riding so high in early 2022 that an FTX executive felt comfortable directly emailing Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, to ask him to meet with Sam Bankman-Fried, the soon-to-be-disgraced founder of the cryptocurrency exchange.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: What the U.S.-China Chip War Means for a Critical American Ally
articles.snippet: South Korea’s vital semiconductor sector depends on China. A deadline looms for how it could be affected by U.S. efforts to control China’s tech advance.
articles.abstract: South Korea’s vital semiconductor sector depends on China. A deadline looms for how it could be affected by U.S. efforts to control China’s tech advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samsung and SK Hynix, the semiconductor titans of South Korea, have spent over $52 billion to build up their operations in China. Business with China has long made up a sizable portion of their sales.
articles.byline: By John Liu and Jin Yu Young

articles.headline: Storm Delivers a Trans-Atlantic Gift: North American Birds
articles.snippet: Hurricane Lee brought warblers and other colorful species rarely seen in Britain and Ireland for what will most likely be a temporary visit.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Lee brought warblers and other colorful species rarely seen in Britain and Ireland for what will most likely be a temporary visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen species of North American birds rarely seen in Britain and Ireland have been spotted along the countries’ western shores after being blown off their usual migration routes by remnants of Hurricane Lee and surviving the perilous journey across the Atlantic, experts said.

articles.headline: U.S. Government Shutdown Is Unlikely to Cause an Immediate Recession
articles.snippet: White House and Wall Street estimates suggested the economy could withstand a brief shutdown, with risks mounting the longer it lasts.
articles.abstract: White House and Wall Street estimates suggested the economy could withstand a brief shutdown, with risks mounting the longer it lasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for a potential government shutdown.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Madeleine Ngo
